to the US SEC and PACOB rules

introduced a transition framework for addressing inadvertent independence violations associated with merger and acquisition transactions. The transition framework is intended to allow an auditor and its audit client to transition as soon as practicable out of impermissible services or relationships that cannot reasonably be ceased prior to the closing of a transaction in an orderly manner. Such services or relationships may require a transition period so that they do not adversely disrupt the client’s business.

Management should develop procedures for the timely identification of new affiliates of the entity under audit as a result of acquisitions by the entity under audit or its parent entities. These procedures are required in order to apply the M&A transition framework. It is important to comply with US Independence Policy Section 402.2,
Mergers and acquisitions transition framework – US SEC audit clients
to ensure that all requirements of the M&A transition framework are met.
If all the conditions in US Independence Policy Section 402.2 are met, including but not limited to identifying the impermissible services or relationships
prior to the effective date of the transaction

, then such services or relationships are not independence breaches if the audit engagement team concludes that such services do not impair their objectivity. If impermissible services or relationships cannot be terminated prior to the effective date of the transaction without causing significant disruption to the audit client, and the engagement team intends to apply the transition framework, consultation with Independence is required. An M&A consultation framework template for documenting such consultations can be found on the
Any independence issues identified relating to an affiliate of a US SEC audit client must be reported to the GCSP or lead audit partner assigned to the US SEC audit client.

If there are engagements that were opened more than two years after the associated GTAC or PACE folder was created, or engagement codes that have been open for several years for engagements that would not be expected to continue for several years, confirm with the respective engagement partner that such engagements are in compliance with the Client

and Engagement Acceptance Global Policy (e.g., the engagement was appropriately approved in PACE, any changes to the scope of the engagement have been appropriately approved on an additional PACE form, there is a distinct statement of work associated with each engagement code, each engagement is appropriately recorded in Mercury/GFIS). Confirm that the code should remain open if the project is ongoing. If the project is not ongoing or is complete, the code should be moved to closing status or closed, unless there is a valid reason to leave it open.

For subsidiaries of EU PIE audit clients (located inside or outside the EU) confirm that

scope of service does not include financial statement preparation or assistance with financial statement preparation, including, but not limited to, statutory financial statement preparation or assistance. EU Regulation 537/2014 article 5.1 (c) prohibits the firm providing “bookkeeping and preparing accounting records and financial statements”. This prohibition is extraterritorial and extends to all subsidiaries of the EU PIE globally,
including subsidiaries audited by network firms

The following table provides guidance regarding the
programs that must be completed to evidence compliance with independence standards at the engagement level in the respective scenarios described below:

In situations where multiple fund audit clients (registered or unregistered) may be sponsored or advised by the same investment adviser or manager, or which operate under common control, one copy of the independence program may be completed annually to cover all of the fund audit clients and their affiliates, as defined by the applicable independence rules. The same approach could also apply to other industries, such as insurance audit clients that may have insurer entities operating in multiple locations and which operate under common control
, or other audit client groups when separate reports are issued for controlled affiliates within the same group and each of the audit
reports are completed by the same audit engagement team

The audit period is the period covered by the financial statements being audited or reviewed. The professional engagement period is the period of the engagement to audit or review the financial statements or to prepare an audit or review report. This period begins on the earlier of the signing of an engagement agreement (or similar agreement) or the commencement of audit or review procedures, whichever is earlier.

Refer to Form 1010 to determine whether an audit client meets the definition of a Very Simple Entity. Refer to Form 801 to determine whether an audit client meets the definition of an NCE and see Appendix I to this program to determine whether an NCE audit client meets the additional criteria to complete the simplified version of the Global annual independence program (Form 820).
These procedures refer to a controlled affiliate,
A controlled affiliate can also include registered or unregistered funds that are advised or managed by an adviser audit client and deemed to be controlled by the adviser audit client.
Refer to EYG Independence Policy Glossary, Public Interest Entity:
A listed entity (as defined in the EYG Independence Policy); and

An entity (a) defined by regulation or legislation as a PIE or (b) for which the audit is required by regulation or legislation to be conducted in compliance with the same independence requirements that apply to the audit of listed entities. Such regulation may be promulgated by any relevant regulator, including an audit regulator.
EU/EEA definition of a PIE includes the following
Entities governed by the law of a Member State whose transferable securities (i.e., debt or equity) are admitted to trading on a regulated market in the EU;
In addition, EU Member States may designate other companies as PIEs
whose financial statements or other information are being audited or reviewed by EY, and any entities consolidated or accounted for under the equity method in the financial statements of the entity

The action menu can be accessed from the GIS homepage by searching for the name of the entity, clicking on the name of the entity and then clicking the three dot ellipsis beside the entity name, or from the Tree View screen by standing on the entity and then clicking the three dot ellipsis beside the entity name.
Examples of a close relationship include
but may not be limited to
, close or best friends, intimate or other close relationships with

include dating, frequent entertaining, sharing a residence, vacationing, or non-business related overnight trips. Gifts that are not commensurate with the normal courtesies of business and social life may be indicative of a close relationship.
Refer to the EYG Independence Policy in these situations and consultation is encouraged
with your local country or Region independence team.

Typically, this is the country used to determine the relevant “office” for identification of “category 4 covered persons” (defined in the EYG Independence Policy as “any other partner located in the office in which the lead audit engagement partner is located”).

If the lead audit engagement partner is based in a different country than the “primary country,” the country where the lead audit engagement partner is based should be used for purposes of determining “category 4 covered persons.” In these instances, coordination with your local
ndependence team is encouraged, to ensure that the appropriate location is considered in determining covered persons.

In a group situation, when component teams are located in the same country as the Primary Team and the Primary Team has elected to include them in the confirmation, the team members include such component team members.

The action menu can be accessed from the GIS homepage by searching for the name of the entity, clicking on the name of the entity and then clicking the three dot ellipsis beside the entity name, or from the Tree View screen by standing on the entity and then clicking the three dot ellipsis beside the entity name.

If the GIS tree is in the process of being updated by GDS when these independence procedures are complete, follow-up with the GDS team to confirm that the appropriate updates have been made to the GIS tree.

A breach, as referred to in the EYG Independence Policy, is an instance of non-compliance with the independence requirements of the applicable professional standards (such as the IESBA Code of Ethics) or regulations (such as the US SEC regulations). The applicable professional standards and/or regulations will depend on the audit client involved in a particular situation.

These procedures refer to a controlled affiliate, which includes subsidiaries, other affiliates or related entities as defined under the applicable independence rules. A controlled affiliate can also include registered or unregistered funds that are advised or managed by an adviser audit client and deemed to be controlled by the adviser audit client.

xsd:element.name: DocumentSetDescription
xsd:element.ma:description: A description of the Document Set

xsd:element.name: CMS_AssignedSMR
xsd:element.ma:description: Subject Matter Reviewer for Field requests

xsd:element.name: EYEYAuthors
xsd:element.ma:description: Identify the authors of this file

xsd:element.name: ExternalSource
xsd:element.ma:description: Identify the organization(s) that produced this file (if applicable); e.g., “Gartner Inc.,” “Greenpeace”. Separate multiple values with a semi-colon (;)

xsd:element.name: EYKComments
xsd:element.ma:description: This is for users to be able to include a note to themselves that this document might require special handling.

xsd:element.name: CMS_Destination
xsd:element.ma:description: Target location for the source content to be sent to.

xsd:annotation.xsd:documentation: This value indicates the number of saves or revisions. The application is responsible for updating this value after each revision.
